original_title: China-Linked DKnife AitM Framework Targets Routers for Traffic Hijacking, Malware Delivery
selection_reasoning: This represents a sophisticated long-term infiltration of critical infrastructure - the kind of patient, methodical corruption of trusted pathways that makes for excellent folklore. The concept of compromising routers and edge devices translates perfectly to corrupting crossroads and border checkpoints.

field_note.title: The Corrupted Crossroads
field_note.subtitle: When the pathways themselves become the trap
field_note.excerpt: The most insidious corruption is not of the destination, but of the very roads that carry travelers to their fate.
field_note.epigraph: Trust not the path that has been too convenient for too long.
body_paragraphs: In the borderlands where kingdoms meet, where traders' caravans pause and messages change hands, an ancient form of banditry has evolved into something far more sinister. The corruption I now chronicle does not merely waylay travelers for their gold-it transforms the very crossroads into instruments of deception, turning trusted pathways into elaborate snares.

For seven years, patient architects have been placing their agents not in the great halls or treasuries, but at the humble waypoints where traffic naturally flows. These are the border stations, the crossroads inns, the ferry operators-positions that seem mundane yet touch every communication and transaction that passes through a realm. By corrupting these chokepoints, the infiltrators gain something more valuable than any single theft: the ability to read, redirect, or poison any message that travels the kingdom's roads.

The elegance of this strategy reveals itself in its invisibility. Merchants and messengers continue their journeys, unaware that their routes have been compromised. Letters arrive at their destinations, but perhaps not unchanged. Goods reach their markets, but the manifests may have been studied, copied, or altered in transit. The kingdom's communications flow normally, save for the invisible current that now carries copies of everything to distant shores.

What makes this corruption particularly insidious is how it exploits the very nature of trust in established pathways. Kingdoms invest great effort in securing their capitals, their treasuries, their military installations. But the humble border stations, the routine checkpoints, the everyday infrastructure of communication-these are often protected by little more than custom and assumption. The corruptors understand that controlling the mundane mechanisms of daily governance can be more valuable than any fortress.
